Review Single-atom catalysts for CO oxidation, CO2 reduction, and O2 electrochemistry Wenyu Yuan a ⁎ Yiyuan Ma b Heng Wu b Laifei Cheng b a Department of Physics, Tokyo Metropolitan University, Hachioji, Tokyo 192-0397, Japan Department of Physics Tokyo Metropolitan University Hachioji Tokyo 192-0397 Japan Department of Physics, Tokyo Metropolitan University, Hachioji, Tokyo 192-0397, Japan b Science and Technology on Thermostructural Composite Materials Laboratory, Northwestern Polytechnical University, Xi'an 710072, Shaanxi, China Science and Technology on Thermostructural Composite Materials Laboratory Northwestern Polytechnical University Xi'an 710072 Shaanxi China Science and Technology on Thermostructural Composite Materials Laboratory, Northwestern Polytechnical University, Xi'an 710072, Shaanxi, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract This review introduces the unique features and the synthesis strategies of SACs, summarizes the engineering of SACs for CO x and O2 chemistry, and reveals the synthesis – structure –property – mechanism – design principle relation. CO x (x = 1, 2) and O2 chemistry play key roles in tackling global severe environmental challenges and energy issues. To date, the efficient selective electrocatalytic transformations of CO x -carbon chemicals, and O2-hydrogenated products are still huge challenges. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) as atomic-scale novel catalysts in which only isolated metal atoms are dispersed on supports shed new insights in overcome these obstacles in CO x and O2 chemistry, including CO oxidation, CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR), oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). In this review, the unique features and advanced synthesis strategies of SACs from a viewpoint of fundamental synthesis design are first highlighted to guide future strategy design for controllable SAC synthesis. Then, the to-date reported CO2RR, CO oxidation, OER, and ORR mechanism are included and summarized. More importantly, the design principles and design strategies of improving the intrinsic activity, selectivity, and stability are extensively discussed and the engineering strategy is classified as neighbor coordination engineering, metal-atom engineering, and substrate engineering. Via the comprehensive review and summary of state-of-the-art SACs, the synthesis – structure – property – mechanism – design principle relation can be revealed to shed lights into the structural construction of SACs. Finally, we present an outlook on current challenges and future directions for SACs in CO x and O2 chemistry. Vast attention has been devoted to developing efficient energy storage and conversion devices, including batteries, supercapacitors, solar cells, photocatalysis, and electrocatalysis, etc., to reduce both energy consumption and CO2 emission over the past two decades [2,3]. O2 and CO2 as two common and easily obtainable gases in the earth’s atmosphere are potential precursors for other chemical products and energy carriers, thus motiving numerous research to fully utilize them instead of fossil fuels. The transformation of CO2 to other chemical products not only can directly reduce the amounts of CO2 in the atmosphere, these chemical products (e.g. CH4, C2H5OH, CH3OH) are also efficient chemical fuels to replace fossil fuels, while CO poisoning is a major obstacle for the utilization of CO2 [4]. Recent research demonstrated that CO poisoning not only harms the electrocatalytic transformation of chemical products from CO2, but also highly affects the performance of batteries [5]. O2 with a large percentage of ~ 20% in the ambient atmosphere is also an extremely important chemical for the production of clean energy and other energy technologies (e.g. water splitting, fuel cells) [6,7]. Moreover, the development of Metal-CO2 rechargeable batteries and Metal-O2 batteries further underscores the importance of the chemistry study on CO2, CO, and O2, in which CO on the one is one of the major discharge products in Metal-CO2 batteries, on the other hand CO largely affect the performance of batteries as we discussed above [8,9]. A comprehensive understanding of CO chemistry, CO2 chemistry, and their interconversion is of great significance of the development rechargeable CO2 batteries. Therefore, the development of CO x chemistry and O2 chemistry is of great significance for both energy conversion and storage fields. The electrocatalytic technology also provides a basic platform to understand their electrochemical mechanism which can be further applied to other CO x and O2 technologies, including photocatalytic CO x /O2 transformation, and batteries, etc. However, owing to the extremely high bonding energies (806 kJ mol−1 for C=O in CO2 [10], 498 kJ mol−1 for O=O bond for O2, 1072 kJ mol−1 for C–O in CO, respectively), their corresponding efficient electrocatalytic transformations are still challenging. To overcome these obstacles, great efforts on the design of highly active heterogeneous catalysts have been taken in recent years from metals to alloys [11], from microscale to nanoscale, from zero-dimensional (0D) to three-dimensional (3D) structure, and from single phase to composites [12,13]. Despite of great advances in these design strategies, the utilization of catalyst active sites is not efficient because that only exposed active sites on the surface of these catalysts can be utilized while their inner sites are wasted. Thus, the construction of efficient catalysts with ~ 100% atom utilization becomes a rising star in electrochemical fields. It is widely recognized that the catalytic activity generally increases with the decreasing size of the particles because more active sites can be exposed [14,15]. According to this trend, a desired atom utilization of ~ 100% can be obtained from an atomically dispersed catalyst in which every active site can be exposed and involved into the electrochemical reaction. Since Zhang et al. firstly reported the remarkable activity of atomically dispersed Pt atoms on FeO x in 2011 [16], the single atom catalysts (SACs) attracted growing attention and achieved significant progress in the construction of SACs and energy-related applications have been achieved. Furthermore, the rising of SACs also aroused considerable interests in the local environment of active sites, such as coordination number (CN), electronegativity, and the nearest neighbor atoms, etc. [17]. Thus, the atomic-scale mechanism including the absorption–desorption of intermediates, and the thermodynamics and kinetics process, etc., has been extensively studied while plenty of SACs with diversiform supports and coordination environment has been constructed. This review mainly focuses on the applications of SACs in two kinds of CO x chemistry: i) CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) and ii) CO oxidation, and two kinds of O2 electrocatalytic chemistry: i) oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and ii) oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) that are also most widely studied electrocatalytic reactions compared to other electrocatalytic technologies, and figure out the common and uncommon design principles in these two different fields. Although some reviews summarized the progress of SACs on electrocatalysis, a comprehensive perspective on the roles and design thoughts of SACs for both CO x and O2 chemistry is still blank. Besides, considering the rapid development of this field, the literature and advances are required to be timely updated. We first introduce the advanced synthesis strategies of SACs from a viewpoint of the fundamental synthesis approach design. Then, the to-date reported CO2RR, CO oxidation, OER, and ORR mechanism are summarized. More importantly, the design principles and design strategies of improving the intrinsic activities, stabilities are described to guide further SAC structure construction, including the neighbor coordination engineering, metal-atom engineering, substrate engineering, etc (Scheme 1 ). At last, we present an outlook on the major challenges and future directions for CO x chemistry, O2 chemistry, and SACs. 2 Features and synthesis of SACs 2.1 Unique features of SACs SACs are defined that only isolated metal atoms are dispersed on supports without any appreciable interaction between these metal atoms, in which the active sites are the metal atom and its neighboring atoms (e.g. N, O, S, and C) or other functional species [18]. Such SACs possess unique properties different from conventional catalysts. High atom utilization. The aggregation inevitably leads to the decrease of utilization and reducing the activity. Each active site is fully exposed in SACs, leading to maximum utilization of atoms (~100% for desired, fully exposed SACs). In contrast to non-single-atom-based catalysts including clusters, nanoparticles (NPs), and composites, SACs reach their limits in terms of the rational design at the atomic level, leading to a superior specific activity [19]. Besides, the high utilization can promote the employment of noble metals because their mass loading can be highly reduced to reach the desired activity meanwhile the high intrinsic activity can be fully utilized. Quantum effects . Generally, the interactions between substrates and supported metals increase with the decreasing size of the particles [20]. Thus, benefiting from the quantum effects, the strong interactions between substrates and single metal atoms can highly enhance the stability, improve the density of electrons, and accelerate the interfacial charge transfer [21]. Moreover, charge-transfer effects of the substrates and single metal atoms is helpful for stabilizing single atoms during synthesis, while strong covalent metal-support interaction is another important trapping strategy for the synthesis of SACs [22]. In the electrocatalytic area, many efficient catalysts suffer from poor stability. For example, various non-oxides are easily oxidized during OER in alkaline media, while the metals are dissolved into solution during hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [23]. The strong support-metal interaction of SACs sheds insights to overcome this challenge. Tunable intrinsic activity and selectivity . SACs not only highly promote the utilization of active sites to ~ 100%, but also offer the possibility to regulate the intrinsic activity, selectivity, and stability. The modification strategies carried out in previous non-SACs such as specific surface area (SSA) improvement (e.g. regulation on particle size, morphology), electrical conductivity enhancement (e.g. composites, defect engineering), mass transport modification (e.g. hierarchical structure, surface charge modification) cannot regulate the intrinsic activity of active sites [24]. For instance, the intrinsic activity of carbon-supported metals origins from the M−N x species. Even though the SSA and electrical conductivity can be improved to enhance the apparent activity via structural design, the intrinsic activity of M−N x species has not been strengthened. In the case of SACs, the low coordination state around metal atoms can be freely regulated and further affecting the intrinsic activity, selectivity as well as stability [25]. Notably, SACs dim the boundary of heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysis, thereby capturing the advantages of both worlds [26]. Atomic-scale platform for fundamental study . SAC family provides a platform to understand the structure − activity relations at the atomic scale [10]. Despite that thousands of efficient catalysts have been prepared and the relations of property-material have been widely studied, the intrinsic origins of activities have not been revealed owing to the limited characterization technologies and inaccessible material synthesis strategies [27]. Non-SACs not only possess various diverse chemical bonds, they also suffer from huge difficulty in the control of single variables, thereby leading to that tremendous reported works only focused on the external correlations between structures and properties (e.g. the effects of morphology, composites, electrical conductivity) despite the fact that the high activities of catalysts origins from the single active sites. SACs have significant advantages in achieving single variable environment and high chemical bonding designability, such as the control of neighboring atoms (N, O, S, etc.), metal atoms (Fe, Co, Pt, Ir, etc.), and the coordination number (CN) (the value of x in M−N x active sites), which is extremely hard to be achieved in both nanoclusters and nanoparticles. The development of advanced characterization technologies, such as aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC-STEM), X-ray absorption near-edge spectroscopy (XANES), and X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy (EXAFS), etc. [28], make the direct observation of SACs possible. The SACs provide a perfect platform to study the intrinsic activity origins (e.g. metal valence, CN, charge distribution, and electronic structure) instead of apparent material structures (e.g. specific surface area, 1D-3D architecture, and pore size). 2.2 Synthesis of SACs Owing to the high surface free energy of SACs, the synthesis of SAC is a huge challenge due to the preferential aggregation of metal atoms. Traditional strategies for nanoparticles under hydrothermal environment or high temperature easily lead to the Oswald ripens, which are not fit for the synthesis of SACs. To avoid the Oswald effects, the synthesis design in atomic-scale is necessary for SACs. Many previous reviews summarized the synthesis strategies from the chemical viewpoints (e.g. hydrothermal method, wet-chemical method, pyrolysis method). Unfortunately, such viewpoints cannot deepen the substantial understanding of SAC synthesis because these methods cannot be obviously distinguished with those for NP materials. In this review, we summarized the synthesis of SACs in a view of atomically substantial strategy design, and the synthesis can be divided into three large classes: i) emission-trapping, ii) implantation-confinement, and top-down strategy, which is promising in future strategy design for SACs. The basis of the classification is the key process during the synthesis of SACs. The key challenge in emission-trapping is to trap activate metal atoms, whereas that implantation-confinement strategy is to restrict the aggregation of metal atoms. Essentially, the usual bulk transformation method, atomic layer deposition (ALD), electrochemical method, and partial pyrolysis method can be included in the emission-trapping strategy, while the metal–organic-frameworks (MOF) derived method, hydrothermal method, and template-remove method belong to the implantation-confinement strategy. 2.2.1 Emission-trapping Thermal excitation and laser emission are two main strategies for the emission of single atoms or compound precursors (e.g. Pt-O x species, Ni-N x species) with single metal atoms. The generated single atom is further trapped by the supports to achieve a substrate supported single atom structure, which is the key process in the whole synthesis process of single atoms. Defect trapping. The defects such as vacancies, heteroatom dopants, edges, etc. in substrates are traps to capture the activated single atoms, following by the stabilization via their charge-transfer effects, and achieving the synthesis of final SACs. The engineering of defects plays a critical role in the trapping of single-metal-atoms: 1) the cation vacancies can slightly increase the valence state (e.g. Mo (+4) in MoS2 → Mo((+4/(1-x)) in Mo1- x S2), thereby enhance the binding of Mo1-x S2 hosts with other metal species with low valence state (< +4) of metals (e.g. Pt, Fe). 2) In contract, the anion vacancies would lead to the binding of metals with positive valence states. 3) The heteroatom dopants would lead to the change of charge distribution of hosts, thereby enhance the absorption of metal species on designed position. 4) The edges of substrate usually possess rich functional groups (e.g. –OH, -O), and these functional groups can trap single metal atoms via chemical bonding. Molecular dynamics (MD) simulations suggest that defect is extremely important for the stabilization of single metal atoms [34]. In addition, higher defect density in substrate, higher efficiency of single-atom (SA) dispersion. To date, defect trapping is also the most widely reported synthesis strategy for SACs among all approaches [35]. The defect engineering on substrate to achieve high defect-metal atom bonding, which benefits for the capture and stabilization during synthesis, is the key for defect-trapping synthesis of SACs. In 2016, Jones, and Xiong et al. demonstrated that volatile PtO2 can be obtained and transferred to ceria powders when a mixture of the Pt/Al2O3 catalyst and different kinds of ceria powders are aged in air at 800 °C [36]. Single Pt atoms can be trapped on the ceria powders. This work opened the door to defect-trapping-metal atoms, and then a library of SACs was reported. Cation/anion vacancies of substrates are promising hosts for single metal atoms. Tan et al. demonstrated the Co0.85Se with rich Co-vacancies can efficiently trap Pt species [29]. The Co-vacancy in CoSe catalyst was first prepared by an electrochemically selective etching method, following by the subsequent trapping of Pt atoms (Fig. 1 a). Li and Wang et al. demonstrated that the Ni2+ vacancies in Ni(OH) x are critical for preparing Pt/Ni(OH) x with high Pt loading (2.3 wt%) [37]. Yao et al. directly observed that single Ni atoms were trapped by vacancies in graphene, which provided direct evidence for the trapping mechanism [38]. Besides of cation vacancies, anion vacancies in metal oxides, sulfides, and nitrides are also active sites for single atoms. TiO2 with oxygen vacancies was triumphantly demonstrated to stabilize single Au atoms [39]. Tsang et al. demonstrated that Co atoms preferred to covalently bond to sulfur vacancies in monolayer MoS2, leading to the generation ofisolated Co atoms [40]. Duan et al. demonstrated that the surface oxygen-functional groups and nitrogen dopants were efficient binding sites for metal atoms [41]. By facile hydrothermal process with the assistance of H2O2, freeze-drying, and subsequent annealing in NH3 atmosphere, a family of M−SA (M = Fe, Co, Ni) on 3D nitrogen-doped holey graphene aerogels can be obtained. The resulting M−N−C exhibited an MN4C4 configuration in graphene lattice with the least distortion. A universal strategy via direct transformation of bulk metals into their SA species is considered feasible for large-scale producing SACs [42]. First, the ammonia (from NH3 or cyanamide species) coordinates with metal atoms to form volatile M(NH3) x species. Then, the M(NH3) x species are transported by flow gas, and trapped by the defects on the defective carbon support, forming the isolated metal sites (Fig. 1b). Such thermal emission-defect trapping strategy has been successfully applied to plenty of metal SAs, such as Cu, Pt, Pd, Au, Ni, [30]. Stabilizing single atoms is a great challenge to avoid the aggregation especially under high temperature, thus highlighting the significance of stabilizing strategies. Many works demonstrated that the coordination environment and covalent bonds could efficiently stabilize SAs. Nevertheless, these stabilizing strategies restricted the improvement of mass loading. Hu et al. reported using high-temperature shockwaves to synthesize and stabilize single atoms at extremely high temperature (1,500–2,000 K) [43]. The high temperature provides the activation energy for SA dispersion by forming thermodynamically favorable metal–heteroatom bonds; The long off-state critically stabilizes the single atoms and ensures the overall stability by preventing heating-induced metal vaporization. Very recently, ionic liquid (IL) was found an efficient additive to stabilize SACs due to strong electrostatic interaction [31].An electrical double layer of ILs surrounding supported SA species provides electrostatic stabilization against the aggregation of isolated metal atoms (Fig. 1c). DFT calculations suggest that the presence of ILs significantly increases the kinetic barrier for the formation of M−M bonds, and leading to a thermodynamically less favorable surface for the aggregation. Ligand trapping . Ligands possessing rich functional groups and electronegativity enable the trapping of single metal atoms and suppress their agglomeration. Zhang et al. demonstrated that 1,10-phenanthroline can absorb metal cations on carbon black matrix and further generates single metal atoms via pyrolysis process (Fig. 1d) [32]. A library of SACs (e.g. Ni, Mn, Fe, Co, and their combinations) has been successfully synthesized via this ligand trapping approach in their work, suggesting its universal and large-scale characteristics. In-situ implantation of single‐atom into matrix processes sufficient designability shed new sights into SACs. Zhang et al. developed a facile strategy to implant Co atoms in polymeric carbon nitride (pCN) via a keto–enol cyclization process with a bidentate ligand [44]. The single‐atom Co was generated through the chelation of hydroxyl group and nitrogen lone pair on 2‐hydroxy‐4,6‐dimethylpyrimidine (HDMP) with the Co2+ and Co-SA was immobilized by covalent Co-O and Co-N bonds. Interestingly, the supports-engineering can be simultaneously realized in the in-situ ligand trapping strategy. Through the rational design of ligand polymer, pores and single-metal atoms, an efficient Pd-SAC has been successfully synthesized by Tang and Ding et al. [45] . The pores of ligand can effectively promote the formation of Sn-Pd-Sn intermediates, and the exchange of the ligand and metal precursor, the atomic dispersion of metal in ligand can be effectively realized. Jiang and co-workers demonstrated that ligand is an efficient additive to control the geometric construction of substrates (e.g. pores, morphologies) [46]. Considering the large family of ligand species and high designability, the ligand trapping strategy is promising to provide surprising insights for SACs. Surface dangling bond trapping. Metal atoms trend to migrate to the edge locations owing to the rich free dangling bonds at edge sites [47,48]. Such phenomenon inspired the potentials of surface dangling bonding trapping approach for SACs. In 2013, Schofield et al. demonstrated that dangling bond defects on the silicon (001) surface are efficient to create multiple atomic defects [49]. Yu, Zheng, and Shui et al. demonstrated that Fe-N-C is a promising substrate for the anchoring of SAs owing to the amorphous structure and large SSA [50]. Via stirring and annealing, rich isolated Pt1-O2 dangling bonds were generated, resulting in abundant Pt1-O2-Fe1-N4 active moieties. Remarkably, the Pt1-O2 dangling bond plays an extremely positive role in preventing the oxidation of Fe2+ (known as Fenton's reaction [51]), leading to improved stability. Recently, the surface dangling bonding trapping strategy has been resoundingly employed to bond various metal atoms via M−O bonds (Fig. 1e) [33]. First, the GO slurry with abundant oxygen-containing groups was mixed with the metal foam. During drying process, bulk Fe and the oxygen atoms geometry contact, following by the charge transfer between M0 and oxygen atoms, resulting in isolated Mδ+ species with the coordination environment of M−O bonds. Beside of Fe, Co/Ni/Cu SAs can be synthesized via using the dangling bond trapping strategy. ALD method has been proved efficient for the synthesis of SACs via utilizing surface dangling bonds of substrates. ALD for SACs contains two main processes: i) the reaction of the metal precursor with the surface dangling bonds (e.g. –OH, –O*) of the substrate; ii) the converting of precursors to M−O species to form a new adsorbed oxygen layer on substrates [52]. Sun et al. firstly achieved the anchoring of single Pt atoms on graphene by ALD in 2013, which initiated the applications of ALD in SACs [53]. Up to now, various metals besides of Pt (e.g. Pd, Fe) on diverse substrates (e.g. CeO2, CNTs) have been successfully reported via ALD technology [54–56]. However, owing to the agglomeration problem that comes from that Pt deposition tends to adsorb on the existing Pt atoms during ALD process, it is a great challenge to achieve high metal loading via ALD. 2.2.2 Implantation-confinement strategy The implantation – confinement strategy for SACs involves i) introducing the single atom ions into supports, and ii) transforming precursors into single metal atoms and confining the single atom to suppress the Oswald effects. Similarly, the second process, which can be achieved via the structural design for the confinement of single atoms, is extremely important. Cage anchoring to restrict the migration of metal atoms and strong chemical bonding fixation are efficient approaches to fix metal atoms, and finally obtained the SACs. Importing metal cations into substrates highly lies on the structures of matrix. In most cases, the metal cations can be directly absorbed on the ligands, functional groups, and defects of hosts. Recently, the engineering of matrix has raised growing attention owing to the huge demands on high mass loaded SACs. Electrostatic interaction is a promising approach for the implantation of metal precursors. As shown in Fig. 2 a, a concave-shaped host possessing a negative zeta potential and enlarged micropores was formed via the calcination of mesoporous SiO2-coated ZIF-8 and a subsequent etching process, ensuring the absorption of positively charged TPI ions ([Fe(Phen)3]2+ [57]. After high-temperature pyrolysis in argon/ammonia atmosphere, the Fe-SA/N-C with controlled shape were achieved. MOF-derived strategy is a kind of typical implantation-confinement strategy. The single metal atoms were generated via pyrolysis of the metal atom seeds in MOFs, while the cage of MOF restricts the movement of metal atoms, resulting in a carbon-supported SAC structure. Benefiting from the large MOF family, various SACs with different metals, morphologies, and coordination environments can be synthesized, showing wide applicability and high structural designability. Owing to the appropriate molecule diameter of iridium acetylacetonate (Ir(acac)3) which is between those of ZIF-8 ( 3.4 Å) and cavities (11.6 Å), it can be easily encapsulated into ZIF-8 (Fig. 2b) [58]. During pyrolysis, the ZIF-8 acted as a fence to spatially separates Ir(acac)3 precursors, and preventing the aggregation of iridium atoms. Finally, the Ir-SACs stabilized with nitrogen coordination environment were successfully synthesized, and the geometric construction of ZIF-8 was well preserved (Fig. 2c–e). Li et al. further proved the universality of this implantation-confinement strategy for various 3d, 4p, 4d, and 5d metals. Such ZIF-8 confining strategy has been successfully demonstrated to synthesize various SACs, including Cr-SACs, Fe-SACs, and Mn-SACs, etc [59,60]. Ordered meso/micro-porous materials are ideal confining structures for single atoms against Ostwald ripening, and the ordered well-developed pores enable the absorption of a mass of metal cations. Zeolite defined as a microporous crystalline aluminosilicate can act as hosts for single atoms [61]. Corma et al. reported an efficient approach to stabilize metal species in zeolite [62]. In the one-pot synthesis strategy, the template molecules occupied the intersectional voids, and limited the access of Pt species to this position. Pt species were preferentially located in the sinusoidal channels instead of straight channels. K+ cations were introduced to compensate the silanol groups, and stabilized Pt species. Layered MCM-22 (MWW-type zeolite) with internal dimensions of ~0.7–1.3 nm is another ideal host for single metal atoms [63]. The Pt species were simply incorporated into lamellar zeolitic precursor during the swelling process. After removing surfactant by calcination in air, Pt atoms encapsulated in MCM-22 were successfully obtained. Li et al. first embedded single Co atoms in hierarchically ordered porous N-doped carbon via a template-pyrolysis method [64]. SiO2 colloidal crystals were used as macroporous molds, and a precursor solution containing resol (carbon source), dicyandiamide, vitamin B12, and F127 was infiltrated into the void space of the silica mold, forming a mesostructure. After pyrolysis and removal of silica template, single Co atoms were successfully yielded in ordered mesoporous carbon frameworks. Lou et al. first used mesostructured polydopamine particles as confining substrates to support single Pt atoms [65]. Mesopores were generated during pyrolysis, and the internal dynamic force as a consequence of the mesopore formation fused Pt ions into the lattice of carbon matrix. 2.2.3 Top-down strategy The above two strategies require severe control against the aggregation of metal atoms, and leading to huge difficulty in efficient SAC synthesis. The innovative top-down strategy via reducing the particle size of metal clusters and particles into atomic-scale is promising in overcoming the obstacles of the above strategies [66]. The free energy change during top-down strategy plays a critical role in the dispersion of SACs. As shown in Fig. 3 a, when the free-energy change from nanoparticles to single atoms is negative, metal nanoparticles can be spontaneously dispersed to single atoms, leading to a thermodynamically stable SAC structure, which enables the realization of top-down synthesis of SACs [67]. To achieve the dispersion and stabilization of single atoms, several approaches with strong interaction have been developed to date. Strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) . SMSI is an efficient strategy to synthesize SACs on non-defect substrates [70]. Luo, Qiao, and Li et al. successfully synthesized Pt-SAs on metal oxide substrates in O2 atmosphere under high temperature (Fig. 3b) [68]. High temperature can facilitate the mobility of Pt, while O2 atmosphere is necessary for PtO2 species, thus leading to the successful synthesis of Pt-SAs (Fig. 3c); whereas, Ar atmosphere inevitably promoted the aggregation. The requirements for the successful conversion of NPs into SAs are summarized as follows: i) high temperature to promote metal atom mobility; ii) molecular O2 to partially oxidize the surface of metal NPs, thereby enabling vaporization of MO x species; and iii) a strong interaction between support and metal atoms. Similarly, Jing et al. studied the effects of substrates using SMSI trapping [71]. Ag-SAs are easier to be trapped by (110) facets of Co3O4 instead of Al2O3 under a relatively low temperature (250 °C) in air atmosphere, thereby forming a SA-Ag/Co3+-Co3O4 structure. Very recently, electrochemical releasing of metal atoms and trapping via site-specific underpotential deposition (UPD) was successfully reported [72]. The adsorption of single-metal atoms is achieved via controlling the potential range (UPD region) in which metal–support bonding instead of metal–metal bonding dominates the whole process. The self-termination occurs once the surface reaches saturation, thereby stopping the continuous atom growth, and forming SACs. Transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) are ideal substrates to stabilize SACs owing to their rich isolated distributed chalcogen sites with Lewis base character (such as lone pair electrons, and suitable electronegativity, etc.), thus offering wide universality for a variety of SACs. Strong Lewis acid–base interaction (SLABI) . The SLABI effect recently is utilized to reduce the particle size of metals into atomic-scale. Banerjee, Vajtai, and Ajayan et al. achieved the single atomic doping of 2D materials via utilizing the natural characteristic of empty electron orbitals for Lewis acids (e.g. metallic ions, boron ions, and boron compounds) that can accept the lone pair electrons of 2D Lewis acid materials and form stable covalent bonds [73]. Ti4+ (as Lewis acid) and InSe (as Lewis base) were demonstrated as examples in their work. The empty orbitals of Ti4+ accept lone pair electrons of Se enter, forming [Ti4+ n (InSe)]·Cl- 4 n species. Ethanol as a protonic solvent can be used to ionize TiCl4 into Ti4+, achieving a InSe–Ti complex structure. Owing to the SLABI between PH3 and metal atoms, PH3 could assist the desorption of the metal atom by forming free M x -PH3, the phosphorus (P) atoms were further contributed to the stabilization of SAs, resulting in a P-coordinated SACs [74]. Electrochemical leaching . Electrochemical leaching shows great potential for producing SACs with high mass loading and high purity. As shown in Fig. 3d–f, there is a sufficiently wide potential window with applied voltage in which all of the aggregate metal forms (e.g. particles, clusters) instead of the strongly bound SA are leached out [69], enabling the efficient production of SACs. It can be also used as a supplemental approach to enable the purity of obtained SACs via the above other strategies. Via using the electrochemical CV leaching between 0.1 V to −0.4 V was performed for 50 cycles in acid solution, Co-SAs were successfully covalently (Co-S bonds) bound to MoS2 [75]. The strain which comes from their lattice mismatch and the formation of Co-S covalent bond further lead to the phase transformation of MoS2 (2H → 1T). Although direct acid leaching was also widely used to synthesize SACs, the main purpose is to remove the redundant metals instead of reducing the particle size, which is not favorable for the preparation of SACs with high mass loading [76,77]. 3 SACs for CO2RR 3.1 CO2RR mechanism The electrochemical reduction of CO2 has tremendous potential as a sustainable method to generate chemical energy and fuels. Despite the fact that the single-electron reduction of CO2 to CO2 – requires an extremely high thermodynamic potential (E = −1.90 V vs. SHE @ pH = 7) [78], electrochemical CO2RR undergoes multiple proton & electron-transfer steps at relatively low potentials, which offers thermodynamically favorable energy for the formation of final products [79]. Neverthless, the CO2RR on catalysts undergoes complex thermodynamical and kinetic processes, resulting in unsstified CO2RR activity, which requires the rational design of highly active catalysts. Up till now, vast products, including C1 chemicals (e.g. CO, HCOOH, CH4) [80], and C2 products (e.g. C2H4, C2H5OH) [81], and chemical reactions coming from CO2RR have been demonstrated and the mechanisms have been elucidated. Previous works demonstrated that the metal catalysts are extremely crucial to the final products owing to the bond strength between CO2/immediates and catalysts [82]. In most cases, catalysts with strong bonding (e.g. Ag, Au, Zn) with CO2 facilitate inner-sphere electron transfer to cleave C-O bonds, resulting in the selective generation of CO. On the contrary, weak bonding strengths with CO2 (e.g. Cu, Pt, Ti, Sn) trend to the generation of other formates and hydrocarbon products. the possible pathways for these products from CO2RR are illustrated in Scheme 2 . Studies to elucidate a comprehensive understanding of CO2RR mechanisms are still ongoing. The CO production from CO2RR, which possesses a two-electron, two-proton process, is the closest product to commercialization. The typical chemical equations are as follows: i) CO2(g) + 2H+ + 2e− → CO(g) + H2O(l) (acid media); ii) CO2(g) + 2H2O(l) + 2e− → CO(g) + 2OH− (non-acid media) [84]. The HCOOH undergoes a similar two-electron, two-proton process with a weaker absorption strength of CO2, following by forming HCOO– anion without the cleavage of C–O bond [85]. Electrolytic production of alcohols requires a 6H+/6e- process per carbon following by the equation (nCO2 + 6nH+ + 6ne- → C n H2n+1OH+ (2n-1)H2O) [82]. The complex processes also highly intrigue significant interest in the selectivity and efficiency regulation via system and catalyst design. 3.2 The design of SACs for CO2RR Owing to the great abilities towards controlling the binding energy of absorbed CO, SAs show great potentials for the C1 chemicals (e.g. CO, CH4, CH3OH) production and other chemical products via CO2RR. For instance, Amal et al. demonstrated that Pt-SA/CeO2 is an efficient electrocatalyst for CO and CH4 production via CO2RR [86]. The selectivity can be simply controlled by adjusting the metal loading of Pt-SAs and the test temperature. Finally, ~100% of selectivity for CO production can be achieved. To date, the engineering for SACs as efficient catalysts for CO2RR has been widely carried out and the controllable generation of C1, C2, CO products via CO2RR has achieved great progress [87]. Neighbor coordination engineering. Pyridinic M−N4 species on carbon supports are widely known as the active sites for CO2RR. The roles of M−N4 active sites can be included as i) enhanced CO2 adsorption capacity and ii) improved CO2 activation ability [92]. Although many works demonstrated that M−N4 species are active sites for CO2RR, the fact is that not all sites are contributed to the activity [93]. Shao et al. found that Fe centers in Fe−N4 species hosted by the complete graphitic layer are poisoned by strongly adsorbed CO, indicating that they are not the real active sites for CO2-to-CO conversion [94]. The most active sites are the Fe-N4 moieties hosted by defective porous graphitic structure. The synergistic interaction between the Fe−N4 moiety and the defective graphene layer with nanopores provided balanced *COOH and *CO binding strength, further mitigating the poisoning of *CO and guarantying the low overpotential. Regulating the coordination environment of SACs is proved a powerful strategy to enhance CO2RR performance. Co-N4 demonstrated higher FE and activity toward CO production than Co1-N4-x C x , in which Co-N active site promotes the binding strength of CO2 and facilitates CO2 activation [95]. However, Wu et al. demonstrated that Co-N2 species possess higher efficiency and selectivity toward CO generation from CO2RR (Fig. 4 a–d) [88]. Co-N2 shows lower *CO2 ·- adsorption energy, leading to stronger *CO2 ·- bonding. The strong CO* binding on Co-N2 represses CO desorption, inhibiting further CO2 reduction resulting in a high FE of 94% towards CO production. In addition, when two CO moleculars are bonded on CO-N2 sites, the energy for desorption of the second CO* would be largely decreased, further promoting the generation of CO. The correlation between the selectivity towards hydrogenation and the local CN of Pt-O has been identified [96]. The result demonstrates that high Pt−O CN favors semihydrogenation, while Pt SACs with low CN favors overhydrogenation. Interestingly, Li et al. found that edge-hosted M−N2+2−C8 species bridging two neighboring armchair-like graphitic layers is more active for the generation of CO via CO2RR compared with the M−N4−C10 moieties embedded in a graphitic layer [97]. When the dissociation of *COOH occurs on the M−N2+2−C8 during the CO2RR, the metal atom is active to absorb *CO and the carbon atom next to an adjacent N is the active center to bond *OH, thereby resulting in extremely low energy barrier for the subsequent generation of CO. Based on the M−N4 active sites, Nam et al. demonstrated Ni-SA@N-rGO with Ni-N4 active sites delivered a high CO2 reduction selectivity in CO production with 97% FE at @0.8 V vs. RHE among other M−N4 sites (M = Fe, Co) [98]. Wang et al. reported a Ni-SAC with high CO selectivity via a scalable synthetic approach on commercial carbon black [99]. A current density above 100 mA cm−2 with nearly 100% selectivity for CO was achieved. Moreover, the 10 × 10 cm2 modular cell can easily ramp up to an ultrahigh current of 8 A while maintaining a large CO evolution capacity with a generation rate of 3.34 L h−1. The electronic structure engineering of metal species recently has shown great potential to modify the CO2RR performance. Huang, Zhang, and Liu et al. found that low-valent Ni-SACs with an unpaired electron in Ni shows high CO2 activation activity, achieving an ultrahigh current of 350 A gcatalyst -1 and TOF of 14,800 h−1@0.61 V for CO conversion with 97% FE [100]. Recent work by Hu et al. further underscores the importance of the electronic structure of metal for CO2RR [89]. As shown in Fig. 4e, Fe ion in the as-synthesized Fe3+–N–C was in the +3 oxidation state. The Fe3+-N-C catalyst shows an ultrahigh FE of CO (>90%) (Fig. 4f). Fe3+ sites deliver superior activity from faster CO2 adsorption and weaker CO absorption energy than that of Fe2+ sites. The in-situ XAS spectra suggest that Fe3+ sites possess higher stability during CO2RR than Fe2+ sites (Fig. 4g–h). Substrate engineering. The supports play major roles in the electronic environments for SACs. Mori and Yamashita et al. demonstrated that LDHs supports can highly enhance the electronegativity of SA owing to the special location of their rich hydroxyl groups, further highly promoting the CO2 adsorption capacity [101]. Therefore, high selectivity towards hydrogenation of CO2 to HCOOH was obtained. Vacancies engineering is also an efficient approach to control the selectivity and efficiency of SACs. Deskins et al. demonstrated that the oxygen vacancy in oxide support is the key to activate the CO2 dissociation [102]. With a low energy barrier of ~0.19 eV for Cu-SA on oxygen vacancied-TiO2 surface, which is far lower than that on a stoichiometric surface. Compared to Pt, Cu possess a lower energy barrier, suggesting Cu-SA is favor for the CO2RR. Via controlling the oxygen vacancies of CeO2 supports of Cu-SAs, a high FE as high as 58% for methane via CO2RR can be achieved on Cu-SA@Ce x-1O2x-3 catalysts [103]. Surface vacancy‐enriched MoC serves as an ideal host for single Pd atoms, and shows great potential in improving the mass loading of SAs [104]. Such vacancy-rich MoC supported Pd-SACs delivered high activity and selectivity towards gas‐phase generation of CO (>98 %). The substrate engineering also provides light in the selectivity of CO2RR to generate > C1 chemicals. The keys to generation > C1 chemicals include: i) enhance the absorbing of *CO to avoid the desorption of CO, which is totally different from the design principle for C1 electrochemistry; ii) the subsequent reaction pathway design which depends on the target product. Huang et al. demonstrated that Ir1−In2O3 SAC exhibited high selectivity towards the generation of ethanol from CO2 hydrogenation [91]. The vacancy was introduced to subsequently host Ir atoms in Ir2O3 (Fig. 4m–o). the synergetic effects of partially reduced In2O3 and Lewis acid − base pair between the Ir-SA and adjacent oxygen vacancy (Ov) not only promotes the activation of CO2 into CO* but also enhances the C−C coupling between CH3O*−Ov and Irδ+−CO*, resulting in a high selectivity (up to 99.7% at TOF up to 481 h−1) (Fig. 4p–q). Dopants in substrates are demonstrated to greatly modify the electronic structure of SAC active sites. The sulfur-doping of substrate recently was applied to improve the selectivity for CO generation via suppressing HER activity [105]. Wang and Li et al. reported that the co-doping of N, and S could significantly enhance the CO2RR activity, in which S modulation elevates the Fermi energy of Fe3d and increases charge density on Fe atoms of Fe–N4 species [106]. As a result, the binding interaction between the Fe site and key COOH* intermediate is strengthened, which is responsible for the high intrinsic catalytic activity and selectivity. Besides of doping, pyrrolic-N-C framework substrate is another efficient approach to achieve high FE for CO production via CO2RR, in which pyrrolic-N-C with high local electron density promote the initial CO2 adsorption [107]. Metal-atom engineering. Changing metal species is promising in regulating the activities and selectivity of SACs. DFT calculations on graphene supports suggest that Pt-SA shows high selectivity towards CH3OH generation owing to the weakening of *CO binding on Pt-SACs, while Os-SA and Ru-SA delivered high activity for CH4 generation [108]. Among the family of 3d transition metals, Ni and Fe-based SACs deliver relatively high catalytic activity for CO generation, while Mn and Co exhibit high energy barrier for CO2RR. Although Cu is recognized as an ordinary catalyst for CO generation, Cu-SAC is found to exhibit unique feature to produce various C2 products beyond CO [109]. He et al. designed Cu-SA@carbon nanofibers (CNFs) catalyst with high flexibility and activity for methanol production from CO2 reduction [90]. HAADF-STEM image suggests the uniform atomically dispersion of Cu-atom on CNFs, and EXAFS spectra confirm a Cu-N4 configuration in the Cu-SA@CNFs (Fig. 4i–j). A high FE of 44% for pure methanol generation was achieved because Cu-SA possesses a relatively higher binding energy for *CO intermediate. The DFT calculations suggest that Cu-N4 species show high selectivity towards CH3OH generation instead of CH4 owing to the high free energy barrier for the step of COH* to C and CO generation (Fig. 4k). Ni-SAs shows lower energy barrier for CO generation, which is not suitable to highly efficient CH3OH generation via CO2RR. The nanoholes distributed in the carbon nanofibers of CuSAs/TCNFs are in favor of the diffusing of CO2 to active sites (Fig. 4l). The recent work of Zhang et al. suggested that Mn-SA@C3N4/CNTs with Mn-N3 species were efficient catalysts for CO generation [110].Owing to the redistribution of electrons, the oxidation state of Mn increased after CO2 absorption, which is beneficial for the absorption of CO2 and O2, and reducing the free energy barrier of intermediate formation. Ling and Wang et al. show that a hybrid charge state of Cu0 and Cu x+ for Cu-SA/C3N4 can efficiently promote the selectivity for ethanol [111]. CO2 can be captured on the Cu0 atoms, and then reduced into *CO. The coverage of *CO on the Cu x + atoms is further increased owing to high hydrogenation free energy and strong adsorption strength of *CO on Cu0, and low diffusion barrier from Cu0 to Cu x +, significantly reducing the energy barrier for the hydrogenation of *CO into *CHO. C–C coupling of *CHO species on the Cu0–Cu x + atomic interface further leads to a lower kinetic barrier, resulting in a high selectivity toward C2H5OH generation from CO2RR. Moreover, increasing the metal loading of SACs or the number of active sites is also helpful for the enhancement of activity. Currently, the metal loading of SACs is highly improved. Take Ni-based SACs for example, the Ni-SACs with a metal loading of ~ 1.53 wt% shows a relatively large E onset (-0.57 V) [112], while the E onset of Ni-SACs with a loading of 6.7 wt% is reduced to −0.29 V [113]. Jiang et al. achieved an ultrahigh mass loading of Ni-SAs on N-CNTs (~20 wt%), which exhibited outstanding activity and high selectivity towards the reduction of CO2 to CO (TOF@0.55 V = 11.7 s−1) [114]. Hu et al. achieved a relatively high metal loading for M−N x species (~12.1 wt%) [115],and the Ni-NC SACs delivered a highly improve current density (30 mA cm−2) under a potential of −0.85 V. It is worth noting that the activity is not linearly improved with the metal loading because several SAC sites cannot contribute to the catalytic reaction [84]. Single-atom alloys (SAAs) are promising electrocatalysts for CO2 reduction to C1 hydrocarbons in an aqueous solution [116]. Head-Gordon et al. investigated 28 SAAs, in which the majority component is either gold or silver, in combination with isolated single atoms, M (M = Cu, Ni, Pd, Pt, Co, Rh, and Ir), and found about half of them selectively favor the CO2 reduction reaction over the competing hydrogen evolution reaction [117]. The SAA behaves as a one-pot tandem catalyst: first Au (or Ag) reduces CO2 to CO, and the formed CO is then captured by M, following by the reduction to C1 hydrocarbons. Specifically, for Rh@Ag(100), the pathway is *CO → *CHO → *CH2O→*OCH3 → *O + CH4(g) → *OH + CH4(g) → * + H2O(l) + CH4(g); whereas, for Rh@Au(100), reduction occurs through the pathway: *CO → *CHO → *CHOH → *CH + H2O(l) → *CH2 + H2O(l) → *CH3 + H2O(l) → * + H2O(l) + CH4(g).The calculated voltages required to drive the two electrocatalytic systems are −1.01 V (FE for CO2 reduction to CO: ~60%) and −1.12 V (FE for CO2 reduction to CO: ~90%) vs RHE for Rh@Au(100) and Rh@Ag(100), respectively. The introduction of multi-metals can change the electronic structures of SACs, and enhance the CO2RR activities. Gong et al. show that neighboring Zn atoms can efficiently promote the CO production performance of Co-SAs via electronic effects, which enhance the *COOH intermediate bonding energy on Zn sites [118]. It is worth noting that although many works claim that the SACs are more active than particle-size catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation (e.g. CH4, C2H4), the nanoclusters (~1 nm in size) might be more active than the SACs because of the competitive strong metal-support interactions (SMSI) and H-spillover effects [119]. SMSI effect is interpreted as the electronic interaction of charge transfer and chemical interaction of metals and reducible oxide supports, which accounts for numerous structure − reactivity relationships for hydrogenation reactions. For example, the chemical state of metallic Ir species can be modulated by CeO2 supports, and lead to improved CH4 selectivity [120]. H-spillover effect widely exists in metal oxide supported metal catalysts, in which hydrogen atoms dissociated on M1 sites could migrate to the M2 sites to facilitate the removal of surface oxides and the recovery of M2 active sites [121]. As particle size increasing, the H-spillover effect is enhanced while the SMSI effect is suppressed. This rule indicates that SACs might not be the best choice because of the strong SMSI effect but weak H-spillover effect. For Ru-CeO2 system, Ru nanoclusters (particle size: ~1.2 nm) showed the highest low-temperature CO2 hydrogenation activity with a TOF of 7.41 × 10-3 s−1 (190 °C) and ~ 100% selectivity because a balance of the above two effects in this system is achieved [119]. 4 SACs for CO oxidation 4.1 CO oxidation mechanism The large C1, C2, and > C2 products family of CO2RR further derives various oxidation technologies which are widely studied in electrocatalytic areas, such as CO oxidation, CH3OH oxidation, CH4 oxidation, etc. here, we will mainly focus on the CO oxidation which is widely studied technology owing to its toxic character. Based on the Langmuir–Hinshelwood (L–H) model, the CO oxidation includes 3 steps (Scheme 3 a) [122]: 1) the bonding of CO on the surface of the catalyst which is commonly described by the Blyholer model of M ← C σ donation and M → C π back-bonding (CO+* → CO*); 2) O2 dissociation (T > 170 K) (O2+* → 2O*) [123]; 3) releasing CO2 via the combination of CO* and O* (CO*+O* → CO2 + 2*). The CO oxidation catalyzed by the Eley–Rideal (E-R) mechanism as follows (Scheme 3b): 1) absorbing O2 on the surface of catalyst: (O2+* → *–OO); 2) adsorbing CO above the pre-adsorbed O2 (*–OO + CO → *–OO-CO); 3) The C atom of the CO molecule approaches one O atom in the adsorbed O2 molecule with the cleavage of the *–O bond, releasing a CO2 molecule (*–OO-CO → *-O + CO2). For metal oxides, the CO oxidation may follow a Mars–van Krevelen mechanism (Scheme 3c) [124]: 1) the absorption of CO on the surface of oxide catalyst(CO+*MO → OC–*MO); 2) the absorbed CO is oxidized by the lattice oxygen, leading to an oxygen vacancy in MO catalyst (OC–*MO → *OCO + M); 3) releasing CO2 molecular (*OCO → *+CO2); 4) the oxygen vacancy in the catalyst is healed by supplementary O2 to revert to initial stage (M + 1/2O2 → MO). Termolecular Eley–Rideal (TER) mechanism has recently been identified to be a possible mechanism for CO oxidation (Scheme 3d) [125]: 1) two CO molecules are co-adsorbed on one catalyst site (CO + CO+ * →OC–*–CO); 2) a free O2 molecule is activated by above molecules (O2 + OC–*–CO → OCO–*–OCO); 3) above intermediate dissociates into two CO2 molecules (OCO–*–OCO → 2CO2+*). 4.2 The design of SACs for CO oxidation The size of precious metals plays a major role in CO oxidation activities. The size-dependent relation was studied on Pt/TiO2 catalyst by Christopher et al. in 2017 [126]. The Pt-SA shows superior CO oxidation performance compared to oxidized Pt and ~ 1 nm Pt clusters owing to moderate CO absorbing energy and high active sites utilization efficiency. The cationic interfacial Pt atoms bonded to TiO2 are assigned to the active sites are, and nearly 100% of atoms are exposed for electrocatalysis. Zhang et al. demonstrated that Rh/CeO2 is a promising candidate for CO oxidation Mars-van Krevelen mechanism, and avoiding CO poisoning at low temperature [127]. SACs have achieved significant advances in CO oxidation and attracted wide attention. The possible CO oxidation mechanism for SACs also highly depends on the engineering of catalysts. Substrate engineering. The activation of supports of SACs is extremely important for the activities for CO oxidation. Datye and Wang et al. demonstrated that the low-temperature CO oxidation activity could be dramatically enhanced the activation of surface lattice oxygen that is bonded to H, forming hydroxyls on the CeO2 support near Pt-SAs (Fig. 5 a–b) [128]. The activation of atomically dispersed Pt2+ on CeO2 was achieved via high-temperature steam treatment (Fig. 5c). The DFT calculations suggest that the Olattice[H] is stable as temperature decreasing to 767 °C (Fig. 5d). Remarkably, T100 (temperature required to reach 100% conversion) of CO decreased from 320° to 148 °C. It is worth noting that the active Olattice[H] site generated from steam treatment is thermally more stable than the surface OH on the Ce that is formed by co-feeding water during CO oxidation or water dissociation over Pt/CeO2. The H2-TPR profiles further confirm that surface lattice oxygen is activated for the obtained Pt-CeO2 catalysts (Fig. 5e). Kim et al. demonstrated that CeO x –TiO2 interface stabilized Pt SAs by strong electronic interactions, increasing the mass activity of Pt toward CO oxidation by ~ 15 times at 140 °C [129]. The CeO x –TiO2 interfaces not only activated the interface-mediated Mars–van Krevelen mechanism, also protected Pt SAs from CO poisoning. High-entropy materials recently show large potential for substrate engineering to catalyze CO oxidation. High-entropy fluorite oxides (CeZrHfTiLa)O x (HEFO) were found to stabilize Pd-SAs by forming stable Pd–O–M bonds (M = Ce/Zr/La) [130]. The obtained catalyst affords highly improved reducibility of lattice oxygen and the stability of Pd–O–M species. 2D materials as promising substrates for SACs anchoring and ion transport have been widely studied. ferroelectric monolayer In2Se3 is predicted to be an appropriate substrate due to the negative clustering energy and strong binding energy to Pt atoms [131]. O2 adsorption could be inhibited by CO on Pt/In2Se3 with positive polarization, and switching the polarization direction can effectively solve this problem. Single-layer graphdiyne (GDY) is calculated to be an excellent support for Sc and Ti atoms [132]. C sites on GDY surface with larger binding energies and higher migration barriers than that on graphene are the most stable binding site, which prevents the aggregation of Sc and Ti SACs. 2D metal carbides (MXenes) are predicted as potential supports for SACs. Ti-anchored Ti2CO2 monolayer exhibited noble metal-comparable high activity for low-temperature CO oxidation via considering Langmuir–Hinshelwood (L-H) and Eley–Rideal (E-R) mechanisms [133]. Metal-atom engineering. Considering that the catalytic efficiency highly depends on the species of metal catalysts, the activities of various M/MgO and M/Fs-defect MgO SACs (M = Cu, Ag, Au, Ni, Pd, and Pt) were studied via DFT calculations by Li et al. [134]. Via using the adsorption energies of CO and O2 as the activity descriptors, Ag/MgO and Ag/Fs-defect MgO shows superior CO oxidation catalytic performance among all studied SACs. Prieto and Plessow et al. experimentally investigated the CO oxidation activities of a series of 4d (Ru, Rh, Pd) and 5d (Ir, Pt) transition metals on MgO carrier [135]. M4+ surface carbonates with octahedral coordination at MgO step-edges, were predicted to be the most stable metal species, indicating an analogous active site regardless of the metal identity (Fig. 6 a–c). Apparent activation energies are in the range of 96 ± 19 kJ mol−1 for these metals, in which Pt exhibited the lowest overall energy barrier (Fig. 6d–e). Moreover, this work emphasizes the importance of adjusting the oxide surface chemistry, in addition to the metal selection of SAC catalysts for CO oxidation. Atomic bimetals, which possess more actives, are competitive compared to single metal-SAC. More importantly, the second metal could enhance the catalytic performance of a monometallic site through ligand effect, geometric effect, and lattice strain effect [136,137]. The bimetal active site engineering further provides wide designability owing to the large metal family. Isolated bimetallic sites Rh1Co3 were firstly demonstrated via the oxidation of A x O y -M(OH)z and a subsequent reduction process in H2 atmosphere to form M−A bonds on A x O y substrates [138]. The local coordination environment of the Rh1Co3 active sites and the positively charged Rh atom help to activate the oxidation reaction and improve the selectivity. Bimetallic PtCe site is more active for CO oxidation than single Pt site. In-situ experiments demonstrated that the partially preserved PtCe bimetallic sites and reoxidized Pt-O-Ce sites with a low CN (Pt-O) are responsible for the high CO oxidation performance [139]. SAA strategy shows great potential to tackle CO poisoning owing to the weakened CO binding energy [140]. In addition, SAAs is promising to adjust the oxidation mechanism and dynamic processes. Quantum chemical calculations suggest that the core–shell structure is the most stable structure for Au–Pd SAA benefitting from the charge transfer from the Pd atom to the Au atoms [141]. CO prefers to be adsorbed at Pd site, while O2 tends to form a bridging bond with Pd atom and its adjacent Au atom. The CO oxidation on Au–Pd SAA follows L-H mechanism at relatively low temperature owing to the low energy barriers. Besides of precious metal atoms, non-noble dual metal sites have been investigated as efficient catalysts for CO oxidation. Wu et al. reported that Fe−Co sites on N-doped carbon support can greatly reduce the temperature for complete CO conversion as low as −73 °C with a TOF of 0.096 s−1 [142]. The CO oxidation follows the L-H mechanism, in which CO preferentially adsorbs at the Co sites and O2 adsorbs at the Fe sites (Fig. 6f). Neighbor coordination engineering. The local coordination environment also determines the absorption and desorption dynamics of CO oxidation. Take Ir/Fe3O4 as an example, two- and five-fold sites bind CO more strongly than metallic Ir, and form structures consistent with IrI and IrIII coordination complexes. The six-fold site is energetically preferred, but is subsurface and unable to adsorb CO. Ir incorporates into the subsurface already at 450 K, becoming inactive for adsorption. Behm et al. demonstrated that Cu/UiO-66 in which Cu binds to the MOF by −OH/−OH2 ligands capping the defect sites at the Zr oxide clusters, shows an excellent selectivity of ~ 100% for CO oxidation [143]. The high activities of SACs are not only contributed by the high activities of single active sites themselves but also may come from their surrounding heterogeneous electrolytes. Very recently, the activation role of H2O for Au-SAC on CeO2 substrate was reported by Zhang et al. [144] CO oxidation on the SAC sites is dramatically promoted by the existence of H2O whereas such effect on nanoparticles is much weaker. remarkable H2O promoting effect makes the Au SAC two orders of magnitude more active than the commercial three-way catalyst. Unfortunately, owing to that previous works mainly focused on metal oxide substrates for CO oxidation, the studies on coordination environment are rare. As increasing interests in non-oxide substrates for SAC anchoring, we believe that the issues on the coordination environment will be solved in near future. 5 SACc for ORR 5.1 ORR mechanism ORR proceeds via either a direct four-electron (4e-) mechanism by electro-reducing molecular O2 to H2O or a two-step, two-electron (2e-) mechanism involving the formation of hydrogen peroxide ions as an intermediate. Direct 4e- reaction equations in acidic and non-acidic media are as follows: O2 + 2H2O + 4e- → 4OH- (non-acidic media) O2 + 4H++4e- → 2H2O (acidic media) Two-step 2e- reaction equations are as follows: O2 + 2H+ + 2e- → H2O2, (acidic media) H2O2 + 2H+ + 2e- → 2H2O, (acidic media) Or O2 + H2O + 2e- → HOO– +OH–, (non-acidic media) HOO– + H2O + 2e- → 3OH– (non-acidic media) The possible reaction pathways for ORR in both acidic and non-acidic media are schemed schematized in Scheme 4 . There are mainly three pathways for ORR after the absorption of an O2 molecule on the catalyst surface that is distinguished by the manner of the cleavage of O=O bond: i) dissociation mechanism; ii) associative mechanism; and iii) peroxo pathway [145]. The dissociation mechanism can be concluded as follows: The O=O bond directly dissociate into two absorbed *O firstly, and then the O* continuously reacts with a proton and an electron to form *OH. Finally, the *OH is further reduced by a proton together with one electron transfer to form an absorbed H2O molecule. After releasing the generated molecular H2O, a whole electrocatalytic cycle ends and the catalyst returns to the initial state. This series of chemical reactions are given below: *O2 → *O + *O, *O + H+ + e- → *OH, *OH + H+ + e- → H2O*; The association mechanism as another 4e- mechanism, is more complicated than the dissociation mechanism. First, the O2 is reduced to form *OOH via hydrogen ion and one electron transfer. Second, the O−O bond cleavage happens in the *OOH product. After that, the O* is continuously reduced by a similar pathway in the dissociation mechanism. This series of chemical reactions are given below: *O2 + H+ + e- → *OOH, *OOH → *O + *OH, *O + H+ + e- → *OH, *OH + H+ + e- → H2O*; Besides of above 4e- pathways, the two-step, 2e- mechanism possibly exists in ORR. Two protons combine with absorbed *O2 to form *HOOH, following by the dissociation of *HOOH to two *OH species. After that, the *OH species is reduced by the hydrogen and an electron to form molecular water. This series of chemical reactions are given below [146]: *O2 + 2H+ + 2e- → *HOOH, *HOOH → *OH + *OH *OH + H+ + e- → H2O*. In a non-acidic media, H2O rather than H3O+ acts as the proton donor, and the reaction steps in the ORR change accordingly. For association and two-step, 2e- mechanism, no obvious change happens, whereas the reaction equations in dissociation pathway largely change and given below [147,148]: O2∗ + H2O (l) + e- → ∗OOH + OH–, ∗OOH + e- → ∗O + OH–, ∗O + H2O (l) + e- → *OH + OH–, ∗OH + e- → OH– + ∗ 5.2 The design of SACs for ORR Single-atom-iron catalysts with ultrahigh activity and nonprecious features attracted great attention. The superior ORR performance of SA-Fe on NG (SA-Fe/NG) is attributed to the Fe-N4 species, which is widely recognized [149,150]. Cao et al. revealed that the formation of Fe-pyrrolic-N species is the origin of high-ORR activity of SA-Fe/NG, in which such coordination environment creates a Fe atom and 8 of C atom active sites next to pyrrolic N, and increasing the amounts of active sites in an order of magnitude [151]. Although high-spin O x -Fe3+-N4 configuration may exist in some Fe-SACs, it is easily switched to HO–*Fe2+-N4 during the ORR process, thus delivering excellent ORR performance [152]. Very recently, an unconventional ORR mechanism ((O2 → OOH* → 2OH* → OH* → H2O) on SACs (especially for Fe-SACs), which is totally different from previous well-known 4e--mechanism (O2 → OOH* → O* → OH* → H2O (O* mechanism) was found by Li et al. [153]. Here, we suggest that both general O* and unconventional 2OH* mechanisms are better to be taken into consideration in theoretical simulations and experimental study of SACs for ORR. Neighbor coordination engineering. The searching of optimizing coordinate environment, especially for the CN in M−N x C y species is still in progress. Lu, Xi, and Zhang et al. reported that Co-N3C1 site was more favorable for ORR compared to Co-N2C2 and Co-N4 [154]. Three types of Co-SAs with different ratios between the N and C atoms bonded to Co atoms (Co-N4, Co-N3C1, and Co-N2C2) were obtained via tuning thermal pyrolysis temperature (800, 900, and 1000 °C) (Fig. 7 a–c). The catalyst with Co-N3C1 species showed a superior ORR performance with E 1/2 of 0.846 V, and Tafel slope of 46 mV dec-1 (Fig. 7d–e). The near-Fermi electronic states of Co-N3C1, which enhance both the electronic hybridization with O2 and the formation of OOH*, are responsible for the outstanding ORR activity (Fig. 7f–g). Via using operando Raman, XAS, and 57Fe Mössbauer spectroscopy, the dynamic ORR evolution and structural variation of the active single-Fe-atom moieties are evidenced [155]. The Fe-N bond length in N-FeN4C10 is shortened with the Fe atom moving to N4-plane, accompanied by the conversion of Fe2+ state from high-spin to low-spin via the formation of O2–-FeN5 near the onset potential. In contrast, the Fe-N bond length in FeN4C12 increases with Fe atom moving out of N4-plane, accompanied by Fe2+ state converting from low-spin to high-spin with the formation of O2–-FeN4 intermediate at higher potential (>0.5 V vs. RHE). The introduction of the M−O bond, which is favorable to the chemical dissociation, is paramount for uplifting the intrinsic activities of M−centered ORR catalysts. The Fe−O−Fe bridge bonds in carbon substrate which were formed by approximating two Fe-N4 sites through increasing the Fe sites, and preventing the Fe atoms from aggregation Zn to were synthesized to study the effects of M−O bonds for ORR [156]. With electron in d orbital of Fe flowing to O. apparent charge transfer occurs in the Fe-O-Fe interface. Thus, the d electrons for O2 adsorption on the Fe sites are reduced, leading to the weakened adsorption of O2 and an ultimately high ORR activity (E onset = 0.93 V, E 1/2 = 0.83 V, ~10 times higher than the Fe-N4 site). Substrate engineering. The supports-structural engineering, as a widely employed method to modify the ion/charge transfer and SSA, is also an efficient approach for the rational design of SACs. The particle size and thermal activation temperature play major roles in the ORR activities of SACs. Wu et al. revealed that SACs with a particle size of 50 nm delivered the best activity owing to rich active sites for Fe-doped ZIF-67 derived Fe-SACs [157]. Further size reduction leads to obvious particle agglomeration, thus decreasing the activity. Besides, this work suggested that the critical temperature to form active sites is 800 °C, in which a reduced oxidation number (from Fe3+ to Fe2+) happens and Fe-N4 species are generated. As further the temperature increasing, the activity is continuously enhanced owing to the rise of graphitic N and Fe-N4 species. Electron charge modification around M−X n sites is considered efficient to promote the ORR activities of SACs. Generally, Electron-withdrawing functionalities induced an increase of ORR activity of M−X n sites, while electron-donating functionalities decrease ORR activity. Lee et al. demonstrated that electron-withdrawing oxidized S (e.g. –SO2) accelerated the intrinsic kinetic activity and improved the stability of Fe-N4 sites owing to the electronic effect of the sulfur functionality [158]. The electrons were transferred from the Fe-N4 site to functionalized graphene in the –SO2-functionalized Fe-N-C catalyst, whereas electron transfer occurred in the reverse direction in the −S-functionalized catalyst, implying that the thiophene-like S and oxidized S functional groups play opposite roles in determining the charge state of the Fe-N4 site (Fig. 8 a–c). The -SO2 functional group in the Fe-N-C catalyst lowered the d-band center of the Fe ion by withdrawing electrons from the Fe-N4 site, whereas the d-band center is up-shifted in –S-functionalized catalysts, indicating a weaker adsorption energy of ORR intermediates for –SO2-functionalized Fe/N/C catalyst (Fig. 8d–e). The modification of carbon supports is another efficient approach to enhance the properties of SACs. Li et al. found that SA-Fe on S, N-codoped carbon exhibits higher activity with an E 1/2 of 0.896 V (vs. RHE) than SAC-Fe on nitrogen carbon (E 1/2 = 0.839 V) [159]. The incorporated S engineered the charges on N atoms surrounding Fe center, and facilitated the release of OH*, and therefore improved the ORR efficiency. Similar results were also obtained on SA-Fe/N,S-codoped CNTs [160]. Introduction of N and S induced uneven charge distribution in carbon, causing positively charged carbon atoms to favor adsorption of oxygen species, and the doping also affected Fe 3d-electrons and largely improved the electrical conductivity of the system. Chen et al. demonstrated that higher electron density preferred to promote the hydrolysis of the M−O2 species, resulting in the formation of 4e-/4H+ H2O instead of 2e-/2H+ H2O2, underscoring the significance of the selectivity regulation via electronic engineering [161]. Liu et al. show that plane-symmetric Fe-N4 sites adverse to the O2 adsorption and activation, resulting in unsatisfactory ORR activities [162]. Therefore, a hybrid catalyst by the coordination of FePc molecule with oxygen-containing groups on O2 plasma-treated acetylene black matrix was designed in their work. The axial O coordination O–Fe-N4 species broke the electronic distribution symmetry of Fe, leading to the electronic localization on O, which is beneficial for the O2 adsorption and activation. As a result, the catalyst shows an ultralow Tafel slope (27.5 mV dec−1) and a superior E 1/2 of 0.90 V (vs. RHE). Edge-site engineering to promote the efficiency of M−N4 sites was carried out for the first time by Chen and Wang et al. [164]. Edge-hosted Fe−N4 species were obtained via the selective C−N bond cleavage adjacent to Fe center induced by porosity engineering. Compared to intact atomic configuration, the edge-hosted Fe-N4 species lowered the overall ORR barriers, thus achieving a low half-wave potential of ~ 0.92 V vs RHE, remarkable stability, and high atom utilization. Fig. 7f–g clearly show that the configuration of Fe cluster and Fe‐N4 (Fe cluster/Fe‐N4) in the nearest approximation delivers lowest E f (21.19 eV) [163]. Therefore, via the introduction of excessive Fe clusters, the energetically preferred Fe cluster/Fe‐N4 structure can be obtained, and finally lead to abundant edge-dominant Fe‐N4 sites after removing Fe clusters. The Gibbs free energy diagrams (Fig. 7h) further confirm that the edge site shows a fairly low overpotential of 0.29 V, 0.6 V for ORR, and OER, respectively. The experimental Fe-N4 site shows the most positive E 1/2 (0.87 V vs. RHE) among all Fe-based catalysts, suggesting the superior intrinsic activity of edge sites of SA. Precursors (such as MOFs, biomass, etc.)-derived SACs with abundant functional groups and controllable pore structures provide high designability for substrate modification. 1D substrates usually possess fast ion transport holes and quick electron pass way, whereas 3D supports provide abundant hierarchical structures and large SSA and 2D substrates are favorable for mechanism study. Jiang et al. reported 1D Fe-SA/NC ORR catalysts via pyrolysis of MOF-545 precursors with 1D meso-channels (diameter: ~3.2 nm) [46]. The spatial distance control of Fe ions in MOF-545 effectively suppressed the Fe aggregation, leading to a high SA-Fe loading (1.76 wt%). ZIF-67 has been the most widely used precursors for SACs among a large family of MOFs. Many SA-Co based catalysts were synthesized via pyrolysis of ZIF-67. These structures with high electrical conductivity, large SSA, and structural controllability demonstrated outstanding ORR activities [165–167]. The engineering on carbon supports which can modify their electrical conductivities, ion transport properties, and SSA, was widely carried out. Ordered mesoporous carbon (OMC) supported SACs also demonstrated high activities towards ORR. Using SBA-15 as a template, Jia et al. successfully synthesized OMC supported SA-Co, and the obtained catalyst exhibits efficient ORR efficiency with a E 1/2 of 0.835 V vs RHE [168]. Li et al. firstly reported a carbon hollow spheres supported SA-Co catalysts via a template-assisted pyrolysis method (Fig. 9 a–d) [169]. EXAFS spectra suggest a Cu-N4 coordination site in the obtained Cu-SA@HSC catalyst (Fig. 9e–g). Owing to the reduced hydrogenation energy of OH* species, high pore porosity and large SSA, the catalyst shows outstanding ORR activity in acid media (Fig. 9h–j). 1D-CNTs were an ideal 1D supports of SACs, which was reported by Lin et al. The obtained SA-Fe/CNTs delivered a high half-wave potential of 0.93 V, and remarkable kinetic current density of 59.8 mA cm−2 at 0.8 V [170]. Yang et al. achieved the successful preparation of SA-Co in carbon fibers via simple pyrolysis and acid etching processes [171]. 3D CNT aerogels were firstly used as substrates to support SA-Fe, and the obtained catalyst delivered Pt/C-comparable ORR activity [172]. Biomass with low-cost and rich functional groups is also a candidate precursor for SACs. Dai et al. firstly reported a cattle bones-derived carbon-supported SA-Fe ORR catalyst [173]. Wang et al. synthesized SA-Fe in N-doped porous carbon via using porphyra as precursors the as-prepared catalyst exhibited superior ORR activity (E 1/2 @ 0.88 V = 0.87 V), and high stability [174]. Ordered porous substrates enable the mass transfer efficiency, thereby enhancing the activities of SACs. Zhao and Yin et al. recently achieved the co-anchor of atomically Fe and Ni on an ordered macroporous, microsized trimodal, nitrogen‐doped carbon substrate (denoted as Fe/Ni-N x /OC) [175]. 3D‐ordered PS template was firstly synthesized via a wet chemistry strategy, following by the impregnation of Fe3+ and Ni2+ via the formation of ZIF‐8 on PS template (Fig. 10 a). After pyrolysis to decompose PS template and carbonize ZIF‐8, uniformly sized and cuboctahedron‐shaped Fe/Ni-N x /OC with an average size of 1.6 µm can be successfully obtained. The3D‐ordered macropores (~180 nm) were interconnected by 30–60 nm mesopores channels (Fig. 10b–d). The obtained Fe/Ni-N x /OC exhibited the best ORR activity (E 1/2 of 0.938 V),and the smallest Tafel plot slope (59.9 mV dec−1) in the O2‐saturated 0.1 MKOH (Fig. 10e–g). Impressively, Fe/Ni-N x /OC also exhibits an outstanding acidic ORR activity with a E 1/2 of 0.840 V (Fig. 10g–h). The effect of hierarchical porous structure on the ORR performance was also investigated, and the results show that Fe/Ni-N x /OC with 180 nm macropores exhibited the highest activity (Fig. 10h). Similarly, Wang et al. successfully anchored the Fe species on ordered macro/microporous carbon substrate using PS as a template, and the obtained Fe-N4 species annealed under a temperature of 1000 °C demonstrated the highest ORR activity [176]. The species of substrates to support SACs have significant effects on the ORR activities. To date, most of the reported SACs were supported on carbon materials. Soon and Lee et al. firstly studied the effects of TiC and TiN supports on the properties of Pt SACs [177]. Due to the differences in adsorption energies of oxygen species on different supports, SAC-Pt on TiC supports demonstrated superior catalytic activity, selectivity, and stability for the reduction of O2. Metal-atom engineering . Different metal active sites usually lead to different properties, thus many other single-atom metals (e.g. Co, Zn, Cu, Pt) were developed as highly efficient ORR catalyst. Gu et al. firstly reported that SAC-Zn is an efficient ORR catalyst. Similar to the active sites for Fe single atoms, Zn-N4 was found to the main active site. A high ORR activity with E onset of ~ 0 mV and E 1/2 of −175 mV (comparable to commercial Pt/C) was achieved. Ir-SA was also proved as an efficient ORR catalyst because the Ir-N4 species can reduce the energy for adsorption energy of the ORR intermediates, thus an ultrahigh TOF of 24.3 e- site-1 s−1 was achieved [178]. Metallic Co, as another transition metal that has been widely employed as an electrocatalyst, also attracted great attention in SAC field. Multi-metal atoms recently were introduced into the rational design of SACs which is promising to break the bottleneck of the activity of single metal and further enhance the properties of SACs. Via mixing SA-Fe and SA-Mn together on carbon supports, the energy for the protonation of O* to OH* can be further reduced, resulting in a E 1/2 of 0.904 V and a kinetic current density of 33.33 mA cm−2@ 0.85 V [179]. The low mass loading of SACs largely restricted the activities of SACs. Due to the poor thermal stability and high surface energy of single-atom metals, high mass-loading usually leads to the growth of single metal atoms. Therefore, increasing the mass loading of SACs and avoiding the agglomeration of these atoms are of critical significance for the design of SACs. Baek et al. designed a Cu single-atom catalyst with high Cu content of 20.9 wt% on carbon matrix [77]. Additional N species can securely trap and protect the Cu atoms, and achieving high Cu content. Remarkably, 54 times higher mass activity and 3.2 times higher kinetic current than Cu nanoparticles @0.85 V versus RHE were demonstrated, in which Cu active sites improved O–O bond stretching and offered favorable adsorption energies of O2 and OOH for 4e- ORR. A unique confined self-initiated dispersing protocol was firstly reported as an effective method to fabricate high loading Cu-SAs dispersed on graphene (Cu/G) [180]. Benefiting from the high loading mass SAC-Cu loading of 5.4 wt%, the resultant catalysts presented remarkable activity towards ORR (E 1/2 = 0.847 V, kinetic current density@0.85 V = 3.787 mA cmdisk −2). Recently, a universal cascade anchoring strategy for the mass production of M−NC SACs which can achieve a high mass loading of 12.1 wt% [115]. The keys to achieving ultrahigh mass loading of SACs in this strategy are the chelation of metal ions, the physical isolation of chelate complex, and the binding with N-species under high temperature. The synthesized SA-Fe/NC exhibits a superior ORR electrocatalytic activity (E 1/2 of 0.90 V and a kinetic mass current of 100.7 A g−1@0.9 V). 6 SACs for OER 6.1 OER mechanism OER is an electrocatalytic oxidation process of H2O to O2, which is a key reaction for water splitting and aqueous oxygen batteries. The reaction equations for OER in alkaline and non-alkaline media are as follows: 4OH - → O 2 + 2H 2 O + 4e - (In alkaline media) 2H 2 O → O 2 + 4H + + 4e - (In non-alkaline media) The mechanisms for OER in alkaline and non-alkaline are different because the energy barrier to release OH– in non-alkaline is higher than that in alkaline. Scheme 5 shows the most possible mechanism that is widely accepted.
