The OER mechanism and the equations in alkaline media can be summarized as follows [181]: i) the hydroxylation of catalyst ( M + OH - → MOH + e - ); ii) the hydroxide in media despoil the hydrogen from the hydroxylated catalyst to from molecular H2O, and lead to an oxidized surface of catalyst with an oxygen atom ( MOH + OH - + e - → MO + H 2 O(l) ); iii) the OH– absorbed on the top of MO, and form MOOH ( MO + OH - → MOOH + e - ); iv) the hydroxide further destroy the M−O bond in MOOH, and generate molecular O2 and H2O ( MOOH + OH - → M + O 2 (g) + H 2 O + e - ). The above process is shown in Scheme 5a (i). Besides, it is possible that two neighbor MO are generated at the same time, thus two oxygen atoms will be chemically bonded and produce O2 ( 2MO → 2M + O 2 (g) , Scheme 5a (ii)). In non-alkaline media, the total OER mechanism is as follows [182]: i) the surface of catalyst is hydroxylated via molecular H2O ( M + H 2 O → MOH + H + + e - ); ii) the MOH release a proton to form MO ( MOH → MO + H + + e - ); iii) the MO is further hydroxylazed via H2O and the hydroxide is directly chemical bonded on the top of MO to generate MOOH ( MO + H 2 O(l) → MOOH + H + + e - ); iv) finally, the molecular O2 is released from the breaking of M−O bond and O–H bond ( MOOH → M + O 2 (g) + H + + e - ). The total mechanism is clearly shown in Scheme 5b. Similarly, the O2 can be generated from two neighbor MO via the breaking of M−O and chemical bonding of O=O bond [183]. It is worth noting that the lattice oxygen is possible to participate in the oxygen evolution for metal oxides, especially for perovskite oxides. When the Fermi level becomes pinned to the top of the O2p band for highly covalent oxides, resulting in electronic states near the Fermi level with substantial O2p character. Via using in situ 18O isotope labeling mass spectrometry, the fact that the partial O2 comes from lattice oxygen has been fully proved [184], in whichnon-concerted proton-electron transfer steps are coupled to the activation of lattice oxygen redox reactions. The lattice oxygen participation mechanism can be simplified as follows: O–M−OO → O–M–□ + O2. This lattice oxygen participation mechanism shed new insights into the electrocatalyst development and requires deep study [185]. In general, the generation of MO* from MOH* (the second step in Scheme 5) is the rate-determining step for OER. Therefore, △G O*–△G OH*, which is the difference between the energy states of two subsequent intermediates, is widely considered as the descriptor to reveal the OER catalytic activity. Generally, the strong ability of surfaces binding oxygen leads to that the intermediates cannot react easily with oxygen, and the total catalytic barrier would be limited by the oxidation process of OH*. High binding energy for oxygen absorption usually causes that the adsorbed products and the intermediates cannot easily release or react with other species, and the total OER reaction would be limited by the release of O2 and the generation of *OOH. Based on the above principle, a volcano plot (△G O*–△G OH* vs. current density or overpotential) can be used to predict the performance of catalysts, and guide the design of highly efficient catalysts. 6.2 The design of SACs for OER Neighbor coordination engineering. The coordination environment of graphene supports highly affects the activities of SA catalysts. Graphene supports with di-vacancies confining Ni atoms delivered high activities toward OER owing to the reduced energy barrier, which is superior to the perfect graphene supports [38]. Gao and Du et al. demonstrated that the CN determines the adsorption strength for intermediates on SA decorated graphene [186]. Generally, higher coordinated metal sites exhibit the best OER performance. Besides, the vacancy configuration significantly affects the OER activity. Ni-SAs with dual-vacancy defects on carbon supports can be easily obtained via thermal treatment and a leaching process (Fig. 11 a), and delivered an order of magnitude higher TOF activity compared to commercial Ir/C catalysts (Fig. 11b) [38]. Further DFT calculations (Fig. 11c–d) suggest that the dual vacancy coordination environment modify the electronic structure of Ni-SA to minimize the reaction energy barrier for OER. The neighbor coordination atoms greatly affect OER energy barriers. The studies on Ni-SAs suggest that Ni-O moiety is more active than Ni-N moiety [187]. Jiang and Wu et al. claim that Ni-O bonding in the Ni‐O4(OH)2 configuration lead to a high oxidation state of single Ni atoms (+2.37), resulting in reduced Gibbs‐free energy for OER [188]. The obtained Ni‐O‐G SACs show a low overpotential@10 mA cm−2 of 224 mV. The effects of CN on OER activities have been reported in many works. Among Three types of nitrogen-doped carbon materials (nitrogen-doped graphene with three and four coordinating nitrogen atoms and g-C3N4), the Co-N4 site is singled out as the most active site for OER [189]. Pan et al. also found that the adsorption energies of intermediates increase monotonically with the number of d electrons for 3d metal atoms. Metal engineering. Dual metal sites that could co-participate in the OER process, are promising in reducing the energy barrier for electrocatalytic reaction. Hu et al. for the first time reported a highly efficient Co-Fe dual metal catalyst for OER [192]. During OER, Co ions are first activated by OH–, following by the incorporation of Fe to form Co−Fe moiety. N-coordinated dual-metal Ni-Fe catalyst demonstrated by shows a lower overpotential@10 mA cm−2 of 310 mV and smaller Tafel slope of 38 mV dec-1 [193]. They claim that the enhanced performance is not attributed by the electronic modification but a co-participation mechanism. However, Lu et al. hold opposite opinions on the mechanism of dual-metal Ni-Fe SACs [194]. Their work demonstrated that the Fe–Ni bond leads to a positively charged state and charge redistribution near metal sites. This charge redistribution facilitates the adsorption of the intermediates on both Fe and Ni sites, thus enhancing the catalytic activity. Chen et al. suggest that the long-range electronic penetration interaction between isolated Fe and Ni atoms, which triggers more favorable adsorption energy between active sites and reaction intermediates, is responsible for the enhanced activity [195]. Dual metal sites also provide high selectivity and bifunctionality for SAC catalysts. For instance, Fe‐N4 sites dominantly promote ORR efficiency, while the Ni‐N4 sites contribute to OER activity [196]. Dual-atom metal is another candidate to modify the electronic structure for OER. Xu et al. successfully constructed dual-metal Fe (Fe2-N6) active sites on the carbon layer [197]. The calculations and experiments suggest that cooperative M−M sites accelerate efficient oxygen evolution catalysis. Substrate engineering. Beside of nano-carbon supports, other non-carbon materials are promising substrates for SACs. The origins of the SAC/metal hydroxides were studied by Zhang and Wang et al. via designing a single-atom Au supported on NiFe LDH (sAu/NiFe LDH) catalyst [198]. With only 0.4 wt% of Au decoration, a 6-fold OER activity enhancement was achieved. The charge redistribution of active Fe as well as its surrounding atoms causing by the neighboring Au are responsible for its high activity. Jiang and Song et al. designed a highly-efficient Ir@Co(OH)2 catalyst for OER in both neutral and alkaline conditions [199]. The Ir SAs are incorporated into the defect-rich Co(OH)2 nanosheets through the formation of Co–Ir species. The optimized catalyst displays highly efficient OER catalytic performance with an overpotential@10 mA cm−2 of 373 mV in 1.0 M phosphate buffer solution, which is attributed to high valence Ir species with low-coordination structure during the OER process. Considering that mesoporous substrates possess large SSA and quick ion/charge transport passway, Lee et al. demonstrated SA-Au on mesoporous Co3O4 catalysts to further enhance the OER activity [200]. With greatly lowered gold contents (0.95 wt%), the catalyst shows twice Au-normalized activity than mesoporous Co3O4. Besides of metal oxides, SACs on metal phosphides similarly show great potentials for OER. Although many works claimed that the origin of high activities of SACs is the reduced energy barriers, Li and Jiang et al. showed such a statement is not applicable to all systems [190]. Instead, for Pt/NiO system, the presence of the Pt SAC weakens the nearby Ni–O bonds, leading to the activation of phase transition from NiO to g-NiOOH, further enhancing its OER efficiency (Fig. 11e). Recently, a well-defined brookite TiO2 nanorod was first demonstrated as a promising substrate for single Co-site [201]. The Co-TiO2 presents a record-breaking high TOF of 181.4 ± 28 s−1 at 400 mV overpotential among reported Co-based heterogeneous catalysts. Regulating the electronic structure via compressive strain from the alloy substrate is another promising strategy to boost the kinetically sluggish OER. Wu et al. investigated different PtCu alloys supported Ru-SAs, and found find a volcano relation between OER activity and the lattice constant of the PtCu alloys [191]. The electronic structure was controlled by the compressive surface strain which is induced by the local configuration (Fig. 11f–j). The optimizing Ru–Pt3Cu delivered an extremely low overpotential of 90 mV to reach a current density of 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 11k). The d-band center of Ru shifts up from −3.37 eV to −2.76 eV because of the compressive surface strain, and a volcano relation can be finally obtained. It was further found that the adsorbed oxygen gains a considerable amount of charge (~0.54–0.59 e-), in which the coordinated Ru contributes only ~ 0.19–0.21 e-. This implies that most of the electrons gained by the adsorbed oxygen come from the Pt–Cu alloys, indicating that the Pt–Cu alloys act as electron reservoirs to donate electrons towards reaction intermediates. Moreover, the substrate engineering is helpful for the enhancement of stability of SACs. Interestingly, Gu et al. first reported a SA-Au/Ni2P structure and directly observed its transformation from the york-shell structure during heat treatment via a dynamic atomic diffusion process [202]. The Au yolks can diffuse and dissolve completely into the Ni2P shell at temperatures of > 350 °C, resulting in the formation of single Au atoms in Ni2P. Under an overpotential of 0.24 V, the obtained catalyst has a 12-fold and 40-fold increase compared with fresh Au@Ni2P and pure, respectively. Remarkably, the obtained Au−Ni2P exhibited much better stability than pure Ni2P in the harsh OER environment. Although the authors did not emphasize the stability enhancement, this work provides new insights for the improvement of the common stability challenge of the family of all nonoxide catalysts for water splitting [203,204]. MOFs not only can serve as precursors for SAC/carbon materials, but they also can be directly used as the substrates to support SACs. Shen, Chou and Wang et al. firstly activated MOFs via on-site forming atomic-scale active species for OER [205]. During plasma treatment, the Co-N bonds in the ZIFs were partially broken, following by a reaction between Co species and O2, leading to rich CoO x species. The formed atomic-scale CoO x species act as the active sites to catalyze the OER, which is responsible for the IrO2-comparable activity. Other members in the large 2D family are also potential supports for SAC OER catalysts, such as carbon nitrides (C x N y ) with rich nitrogen species, 2D-metal carbides (MXenes), etc. DFT calculations suggest that Co@C x N y and Co–O@CN are ideal OER electrocatalysts with a small overpotential of 0.16 V and 0.41 V, respectively [206]. High activity of Co@C x N y may is caused by the lower-coordination feature of Co in Co@CN, which leads to stronger interactions with H2O, and other intermediates than those of Co–O@C x N y . The predicted OER overpotential for β12-boron monolayer (Ni/β12-BM) supported SA-Ni reached only 0.40 V [207]. 7 Summary and outlooks As we discussed above, SACs with plenty of unique characters exhibit great potentials in various electrocatalytic areas. A large number of novel synthetic approaches, including top-down, and emission-trapping methods, have been developed, while their wide applications have been exhibited. Beyond CO x and O2 electrochemistry, SACs also shows great potential in many other fields, such as lithium-oxygen batteries [208,209], fuel cells [210], HER [211,212], N2 fixation [213–215], and photocatalysis [216,217], etc. Despite tremendous advances in SACs, there are still numerous challenges and several issues to be solved. i) Controllable large-scale synthesis of fully exposed SACs. In spite of the truth that many kinds of SACs have been reported, the controllable, large-scale, high-loading synthesis of SAC is still a huge challenge. First, increasing the mass loading of SACs on substrate excluding the agglomeration to further improve their activities is still difficult to be achieved. Second, how to controllably regulate the coordination structures (such as the M, X, and n in M−X n species) of SACs is a major obstacle. Third, the large-scale synthesis of SACs is extremely important for industrial applications. the current status in SAC study mainly focuses on the laboratory-level synthesis, which is far beyond the requirements for extensive production in the industry. Last, the active sites embedded in SACs, especially for the MOF-derived SACs, cannot contribute to the activity, and result in a relatively low utilization of single-active sites. Usually, 2D structure is promising in achieving high utilization of SAs, while 3D wrapped structure hinders the transport of electrolyte. This issue is required to be addressed via the morphology regulation and pore tuning. ii) Characterization technologies for SACs. To date, the characterization of SACs highly relies on EXAFS and STEM. Unfortunately, extremely local structures can be observed from STEM, thereby the global information cannot be precisely obtained. Moreover, EXAFS is not sensitive enough to identify single atoms. In some cases, small clusters or nanoparticles also exhibit similar EXAFS spectra due to the poly-dispersity and disorder effects [218]. Hence, a comparison of EXAFS and AC-STEM for the single atoms, clusters, and nanoparticles is highly recommended to identify the structures of SACs. Furthermore, the development of advanced characterization technologies would be extremely encouraging for SACs. iii) Thermodynamic and kinetic fundamental study for the relation between structures and properties. The apparent activities for electrocatalysis are highly related to the intrinsic electronic structures of the catalysts, including the d-band positions, work functions, and Femi levels. Despite many efforts in previous works in SACs, the fundamental researches focusing on the relation between the properties and structures are still urgently required. The atomic-level mechanism on the intermediate adsorption/desorption energies, reaction energy barriers, the surface charge distributions, and chemical bond variations is still not clear. Moreover, the studies on the active sites of SACs for various electrocatalytic reactions didn’t reach unanimous conclusions, which requires further deep study and careful experimental design. iv) Stability in dynamic catalytic reactions. Although SACs are thermostable because of their strong bonding with substrates, the stabilities during the reaction processes have been rarely studied. As we discussed above, during reaction processes, the surrounding environments are changed [21], thereby leading to the variations of chemical bonds, and the change of surface charge distributions. Previously, many works demonstrated that catalysts in aqueous media suffer from heavy surface oxidation or hydroxidation, such as metal nitrides, metals, and metal phosphides, etc., despite the fact that these catalysts are stable in ambient conditions. Thus, it is of great significance to investigate the dynamic stabilities during electrocatalytic reactions, study the relations between the stabilities and local coordination environments, and provide fundamental insights for highly efficient and stable catalyst design. coredata.dc:description: CO x (x = 1, 2) and O2 chemistry play key roles in tackling global severe environmental challenges and energy issues. To date, the efficient selective electrocatalytic transformations of CO x -carbon chemicals, and O2-hydrogenated products are still huge challenges. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) as atomic-scale novel catalysts in which only isolated metal atoms are dispersed on supports shed new insights in overcome these obstacles in CO x and O2 chemistry, including CO oxidation, CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR), oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). In this review, the unique features and advanced synthesis strategies of SACs from a viewpoint of fundamental synthesis design are first highlighted to guide future strategy design for controllable SAC synthesis. Then, the to-date reported CO2RR, CO oxidation, OER, and ORR mechanism are included and summarized. More importantly, the design principles and design strategies of improving the intrinsic activity, selectivity, and stability are extensively discussed and the engineering strategy is classified as neighbor coordination engineering, metal-atom engineering, and substrate engineering. Via the comprehensive review and summary of state-of-the-art SACs, the synthesis – structure – property – mechanism – design principle relation can be revealed to shed lights into the structural construction of SACs. Finally, we present an outlook on current challenges and future directions for SACs in CO x and O2 chemistry.
